sentences.text: We present a scanning method that recovers dense sub-pixel camera-projector correspondence without requiring any photometric calibration nor preliminary knowledge of their relative geometry .
Subpixel accuracy is achieved by considering several zero-crossings defined by the difference between pairs of unstructured patterns .
We use gray-level band-pass white noise patterns that increase robustness to indirect lighting and scene discontinuities .
Simulated and experimental results show that our method recovers scene geometry with high subpixel precision , and that it can handle many challenges of active reconstruction systems .
We compare our results to state of the art methods such as mi-cro phase shifting and modulated phase shifting .

We use gray-level band-pass white noise patterns that increase robustness to indirect lighting and scene discontinuities . Simulated and experimental results show that our method recovers scene geometry with high subpixel precision , and that it can handle many challenges of active reconstruction systems . We compare our results to state of the art methods such as mi-cro phase shifting and modulated phase shifting .
kg2text: We present a scanning method that recovers dense sub-pixel camera-projector correspondence, achieving Subpixel accuracy. Our novel approach uses several zero-crossings defined by the difference between pairs of unstructured patterns to achieve this level of precision. In comparison, state-of-the-art methods such as mi-icro phase shifting and modulated phase shifting are also capable of recovering scene geometry with high sub-pixel precision. However, our method presents a more accurate solution for achieving dense sub-pixel camera-projector correspondence.
